Award.AwardTitle: Expanding Geospatial Technology Career Development for High School Students Through Teacher Professional Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Power of Data (POD) project is designed to increase secondary student awareness of and interest in careers that use geospatial technology (GST) and data; increase their knowledge of educational pathways to enter these careers; and develop their 21st century workforce skills. Building on successful implementation in Arizona, the 4-year project will be carried out on a larger scale. The project will use a train-the-trainer approach involving some 30 teacher educators, 90 teachers and 27,000 students. Teacher educators will be supported a facilitation academy, resources, and a "living" facilitation guide for teacher educators. will be developed. These resources will enable teacher educators replicate the POD Teacher Workshops in their local areas, resulting in the GST and project-based instruction (PBI) in their classrooms and in out of school activities. Through project-related activities, students will have opportunities to assume geospatial roles and work side by side with stakeholders as they examine community issues through a spatial lens, analyzing data surrounding authentic problems to determine appropriate solutions. The project will research project implementation and what project elements contribute to increase in student knowledge and awareness of GST careers, related career pathways, and 21st century skills. This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM).

The POD project will target both urban and rural settings with traditionally underserved populations and will involve an estimated 30 teacher educators, 675 additional teachers trained by the teacher-educators, and 27,000 students. Project research will investigate key elements that contribute to project outcomes. The POD team will research each level of implementation from teacher educators and investigate how the project contributes to the development of student STEM career awareness and interest. The POD facilitation guide, including case studies of common teacher experiences, student work samples, video teaching cases and ways to connect to local industry, will be available online via print on demand or electronically. Research and evaluation results and instruments will be shared through conference presentations and journal articles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Power of Data (POD) project scaled an effective professional learning and development (PLD) model using a facilitator development approach to reach teachers nationwide.  Teachers learned to enhance existing lessons using Geospatial Inquiry: asking and answering questions through the analysis and communication of data that are linked to a geographic location on, above, or near Earth. These data are often represented visually via online maps created with geospatial technologies (GST). The goal is to increase student opportunities to reason with data, and in turn increase interest in science and technology and careers in these fields. Overall, 28 facilitators, 377 teachers and approximately 4000 students participated in 18 states and the District of Columbia.

Through this effort, the project has disseminated resources for effective facilitator dissemination of Geospatial Inquiry, including a PLD model with guides for implementation and resources and materials that enable teachers to effectively implement Geospatial Inquiry lessons. The project has also disseminated a method for measuring the effectiveness of facilitator implementation, useful for education researchers.

POD contributed to understanding pedagogical methods relating to integration of GST into the classroom, PLD strategies that support that integration, and the impact on student interest in science, technology, and careers in these fields. The project is also significant in that it identifies best practices for scaling up an effective innovation. 

When scaling an innovation, selecting and adequately preparing facilitators with specialized training to ensure they understand the principles of the model is critical. This enables implementation integrity while retaining flexibility to modify for their contexts.

Critical components of GST-integrated PLD identified include highly-qualified facilitators, opportunities to learn with GST, time to reflect on the process of learning, time to design and plan lessons, and to consider implications for teaching, including assessment. Learning to teach with GST is socially constructed and interactions with facilitators and other teacher participants are necessary for learning. Workshops offered by teams of facilitators were slightly more effective at preparing teachers to implement high-quality Geospatial Inquiry lessons.

The POD PLD model prepared teachers with GST skills and pedagogical knowledge to design and implement lessons aligned with research-based instructional practices. Lessons provided students opportunities to engage in the analysis and interpretation of data for the purpose of explaining a phenomenon, answering a question, or solving a problem. Pedagogical practices persisted one to two years after the PLD ended.

Relationships between teacher preparation and student engagement in STEM were examined. Higher teacher GST skills yielded higher student interest in science and technology, and had a slight positive influence on student interest in science careers. Teachers who implemented a GST Career Spotlight provided in the PLD had a slight positive influence on students? interest in science and science careers. 

Results indicate that implementation of high-quality Geospatial Inquiry lessons have the potential to broaden participation in STEM. Students who reported that critical thinking skills improved as a result of participating in Geospatial Inquiry lessons increased interest in science and technology, technology careers, and modestly in science careers. Geospatial Inquiry lessons had a significant impact on students who are traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields.  Female students reported higher engagement in science and higher interest in science careers. Students who identified as Black or Hispanic reported higher engagement in science and technology, and students who identified as Black identified marginally higher interest in science careers.

The breadth of this project can be viewed as significant given the number of students that have gained exposure to GST and techniques. The POD Team has disseminated a process for teaching with GST, Geospatial Inquiry, rather than the use of advanced techniques of GST, therefore, the analysis and datasets that are being used are accessible, tested and verified so that they will continue to be usable by K-12 teachers. 

The project has increased public awareness of GST and GST careers, specifically in geographic information systems. It has increased public GST use, which according to surveys indicating teachers? future intentions, is likely to continue and spread beyond the project.

The Geospatial Inquiry approach can be utilized in any academic field. While the focus was on STEM disciplines, teachers in the social sciences attended POD Teacher Workshops and improved their teaching. This approach has engaged a broader audience in the practices of science.

The structured POD Teacher Workshops have enhanced the professional development skills and expertise of Facilitators. These Facilitators have trained hundreds of teachers in developing and delivering lessons using research-based instructional methods. Presuming teachers continue to implement skills and knowledge they developed and will pass that on to others, an unknown number of classrooms will use GST and Geospatial Inquiry. 

Beyond the classroom, GST and the Geospatial Inquiry process have great potential for helping communities examine and address local issues. POD highlights individuals who utilize GST to solve problems. These examples could inspire communities to do the same.
